For example, according to the Consumer Product Safety Council, each year about 25,300 people are injured and 75 are killed on or near riding lawnmowers and garden tractors. One out of every five of those deaths involves a child, so figure approximately 15 mulched and bagged kids per year. By inference the data tells us that since 9/11/2001, at least 250,000 have been injured by dangerous Lawnboys and Snappers, most of which came from foreign sources. Many of those injuries were similar to those suffered by bombing victims, including loss of limbs and/or extremities or vision or hearing; 600 adults died bloody deaths, and 150 kids have been composted. Duhmasses have responded by demanding more safety devices for these easily available weapons of mass destruction, and even limits on their hours of operation. Message.Title: BAC and WELLS FARGO hunt elusive mortgages --- BUY FNMA ( FANNIE MAE )
Message.Msg: FNMA ( Fannie Mae ) & FMCC ( Freddie Mac ) dominate 90% housing mortgage market of the entire nation. Why buy BAC and Wells Fargo when FNMA is 15 TIMES CHEAPER than BAC and 46 TIMES CHEAPER than WFC ????? Think about it to make right decision, guys. ***************************************************************************************************************************** Bank of America and Wells Fargo Hunt the Elusive Mortgage Loan By Amanda Alix | April 24, 2013 B of A and Wells fight back. Even as Bank of America continues to slim itself down via Project New BAC, it is looking for ways to buck the shrinking mortgage business trend, hoping to keep increasing its production over 50% year over year. That's a tall order, but the bank is using its new retail branch structure to help make that goal a reality. As Bank of America opens more of its more modern branch locations, it is looking to increase mortgage lending at those sites. CEO Brian Moynihan has noted that the bank hired 1,000 new mortgage bankers in the first quarter and has beefed up its mortgage fulfillment department by another 4,000. Moynihan says that B of A will hire more bankers as needed, as well, to keep the mortgage origination wheels turning. That's not all. Wells plans additional boosts to its mortgage facilities in Tempe, Arizona, and has hired more than 5,000 new employees in the first quarter of this year. Apparently, Wells expects to grow revenues by pushing new loans, and picking up the slack that JPMorgan's mortgage department staff cuts will engender. Can Bank of America and Wells Fargo beat the mortgage-slump prediction by engaging in a mortgage-banking blitz? Time will tell, but they surely deserve credit for trying.

Topic.Title: I understand that Morgan Stanley's call for $16 is on the conservative side.

Message.Msg: True hitch, but I'm not getting too upset about it. I said many years ago that BAC was going to eventually become a utility type stock. The numbers won't be spectacular, but they will eventually become steady. Banks should never have been considered as go-go growth stocks. That caused them to take risks they never should have taken. I'm willing to take a little less in earnings if they are steady, solid, and safe.

Topic.Title: I understand that Morgan Stanley's call for $16 is on the conservative side.

Message.Msg: Couple of years maybe even a little less. If they can actually make these expense reductions stick, that will be a major lift to the bottom line. If you remember, before the crash, BAC was one of the low expense leaders with an expense ratio that was heading below 50%. That was one of the biggest reasons for their high profits at the time. So now the ratio is 80/85% I think after the last report? That, in my opinion, is probably the biggest key everyone has been missing. Every reduction in that expense ratio goes straight to profits.

Topic.Title: White House Suggestion Box

Message.Msg: Eligible Food Items Households CAN use SNAP benefits to buy: Foods for the household to eat, such as: -- breads and cereals; -- fruits and vegetables; -- meats, fish and poultry; and -- dairy products. Seeds and plants which produce food for the household to eat. In some areas, restaurants can be authorized to accept SNAP benefits from qualified homeless, elderly, or disabled people in exchange for low-cost meals. Households CANNOT use SNAP benefits to buy: Beer, wine, liquor, cigarettes or tobacco; Any nonfood items, such as: -- pet foods; -- soaps, paper products; and -- household supplies. Vitamins and medicines. Food that will be eaten in the store. Hot foods.

Message.Msg: It is a shame what is happening to this country. It started with Barney Frank's "house for everyone" to create the financial crisis. Bush's biggest mistake - TARP. Obama continuing the Bush mistakes and doubling down, spending like mad. It is truly sad what our kids, and us, will be left with. Topic.Title: It's quite conceivable I could amass 500 Rolex's

Message.Msg: As finely as it does so, a Rolex only runs around in circles saying "tick-tick-tick". 500 would just run around in more small circles, and collectively the noise from them would deafen a halibut: ticktickTICKtickTICKtick etc. A fine meerschaum, by comparison, says nothing, invites thought, and is an engine of purest pleasure. All those watches, and you still don't have the time....

Topic.Title: White House Suggestion Box

Message.Msg: Bush American dream act 2003 THE PRESIDENT: Thank you all. Thank you for coming. Thanks for the warm welcome. It's great to be back at the Department of Housing and Urban Development. This is not my first time here, nor will it be my last. (Applause.) I am here today because we are taking action to bring many thousands of Americans closer to owning a home. Our government is supporting homeownership because it is good for America, it is good for our families, it is good for our economy. During the signing ceremony of S. 811, The American Dream Downpayment Act, President George W. Bush delivers remarks at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington, D.C., Tuesday, Dec. 16, 2003. "One of the biggest hurdles to homeownership is getting money for a down payment," said President Bush. "This administration has recognized that, and so today I'm honored to be here to sign a law that will help many low-income buyers to overcome that hurdle, and to achieve an important part of the American Dream." White House photo by Paul Morse One of the biggest hurdles to homeownership is getting money for a down payment. This administration has recognized that, and so today I'm honored to be here to sign a law that will help many low-income buyers to overcome that hurdle, and to achieve an important part of the American Dream. I appreciate Alphonso Jackson agreeing to step up and become the Acting Secretary of the Housing and Urban Development. I look forward to his Senate confirmation, a hasty confirmation. (Applause.) I also want to thank Mel Martinez for doing such a fine job as the Secretary of this important organization. Mel brought integrity and honor to the office. He did a fine job on behalf of all Americans. And we honor you, Mel. (Applause.) I want to thank all the hardworking officers and employees of HUD. I appreciate your focus and your dedication, your willingness to work on behalf of a better America. (Applause.) I thank very much members of the

Topic.Title: I understand that Morgan Stanley's call for $16 is on the conservative side.

Message.Msg: You're absolutely right about the efficiency ratio being excessive. But to get it back to 50% or less they need to lop off nearly $40 billion from non interest expense. And while they have chopped off over $11 billion in the last couple years, that is a tall order in the intermediate term, especially when the ratio is not going to get much help from rev growth, imo.
